column4: is it possible to install ubuntu without any removable media devices at all?
yes
you can install it from a chroot environment

if you already have linux installed you can set up the partition and use debootstrap to set up a chroot environment and install it that way. it is also possible to dump the contents of an iso to your hdd and boot the kernel/initrd from grub and launch the installer that way
can you dumb it down for me?
see this https://help.ubuntu.com/6.10/ubuntu/installation-guide/i386/linux-upgrade.html
of course it is a bit more work than using the install cd
no, you partition some space and then the debootstrap program downloads the .debs and installs them into the space you gave it
it only installs a minimal system which is maybe 1 GB or so
if you had to you could install into that space and then reclaim the space from your debian install by mounting it as /usr or /home or something later on
is there a reason that you wouldn't install from a cd using the usual method?
it might be easier for you if you install with the netboot method then
if you want to i'll walk you through it, but you would be installing over the debian install completely
no, you can do it without any external media
download hte iso
then mount it and you should see a kernel and initrd in it
after you do that you want to copy the kernel and initrd into /boot and then edit your menu.lst to have a grub entry that uses the kernel and initrd from the boot.iso that you copied
then when you reboot you can select that entry and you will boot into the netinstall
it is kind of hard to explain, but basically it's an environment where / is actually some other path on the system
oh, to do the netboot trick you will need to have the kernel and initrd on a partition that you are not reformatting (so hopefully you have /boot as a separate partition)
